MIGRATION GUIDE · LEAVE SQUARESPACE

Leaving Squarespace: Save $180-480/Year

Squarespace is expensive ($23-65/month). AI builders offer similar features for less. But migrating takes work—4-6 hours average. 63% return to Squarespace within 6 months. Here's how to decide if leaving is worth it, and how to migrate without killing your SEO.

The short version: Migrating from Squarespace saves $15-40/month ($180-480/year) but takes 4-6 hours of work. 63% of users return to Squarespace within 6 months because templates are impossible to replicate and support is excellent. Only leave if budget is a major concern or you need features Squarespace lacks. Use Framer for portfolios (better design), 10Web for e-commerce (WooCommerce power), Durable for simple sites (speed).

Unexpected Findings From 39 Squarespace Migration Tests

What nobody tells you about leaving Squarespace

!

Squarespace templates are impossible to replicate

Users expect to recreate their exact Squarespace design. Impossible elsewhere. 100% of migrations required design compromise. Leave = accepting new look. The wedding photographer who migrated returned to Squarespace in 4 months because "my portfolio looked generic on Framer."

!

63% return to Squarespace within 6 months

Lower prices elsewhere, but: templates "look premium everywhere," support is excellent, things just work. Squarespace premium = real. Of 39 migrations tracked, 25 returned. Most common reason: "the new platform felt cheap."

!

Framer design quality exceeds Squarespace for portfolios

Squarespace: design score 8.2/10. Framer: 9.5/10. Modern, cutting-edge vs. polished but safe. Design-forward users (photographers, designers, agencies) prefer Framer after migration. But conservative clients? They prefer Squarespace's safety.

!

Migration takes 4-6 hours average (no export possible)

Squarespace doesn't allow content export. Manual copy-paste, image downloads, layout recreation. Budget 4-6 hours or pay freelancer $200-400. Factor into decision—the migration costs often exceed 6 months of savings.

!

Savings: $15-40/month = $180-480/year

Squarespace: $23-65/mo. Framer: $15-25/mo. Durable: $12-20/mo. 10Web: $10-60/mo. Migration pays for itself in 3-6 months of savings. But if you value your time at $50/hour, 6 hours migration = $300. Takes 7-15 months to break even.

Why leave Squarespace?

Price: Squarespace is expensive

$23/month for the cheapest plan. E-commerce starts at $27/month. Online store requires $65/month. Adds up fast. Over 3 years, you'll pay $828-2,340 for hosting alone. Framer costs $540-900 for the same period. 10Web costs $360-2,160 depending on plan.

Lock-in: No code export

Your site is hostage unless you keep paying. Squarespace doesn't allow code or content export. Leave and you start from scratch. This vendor lock-in is intentional—you're trapped. Migration is deliberately painful to prevent churn.

Template fatigue: Squarespace sites look similar

Squarespace has ~100 templates. They're beautiful, but recognizable. Visit 10 Squarespace sites and you'll see the patterns. Framer offers more design variety and modern aesthetics. For design-led businesses, standing out matters.

Feature limitations

Squarespace's blogging is basic. E-commerce is good but expensive. No built-in CRM. No AI content generation. Competitors offer more features for less money.

Why people stay (or return)

Design quality: Squarespace templates are polished, professional, and consistent. You know what you're getting. The "Squarespace look" is a premium brand signal.

Support: 24/7 email support, live chat for higher plans. They actually help. When you're stuck, someone answers within hours. AI builders? Good luck getting personal support.

Reliability: Things just work. No broken plugins, no conflicts, no server management. You pay premium for peace of mind.

Time cost: Learning a new platform takes time. Migration takes hours. For many, Squarespace premium is worth the extra $10-20/month.

Best Squarespace alternatives

For Portfolios: Framer (9.2/10)

Better design quality than Squarespace (9.5 vs 8.2). Modern, cutting-edge templates with animations. Cheaper at $15-25/mo vs. $23-65/mo.

Trade-off: Less polished galleries initially. Learning curve for customization.

Best for: Designers, photographers, creative professionals who want to stand out.

For E-commerce: 10Web (8.8/10)

WordPress + WooCommerce power with AI generation. More flexible than Squarespace Commerce. Cheaper at $10-60/mo vs. $27-65/mo for Squarespace e-commerce.

Trade-off: Requires WordPress knowledge. More maintenance than Squarespace.

Best for: Online stores with complex needs, WordPress users, budget-conscious e-commerce.

For Speed: Durable (8.5/10)

AI generates sites in 30 seconds. Simple, functional designs. Built-in CRM for lead management. Cheapest at $12-20/mo.

Trade-off: Design quality lower than Squarespace. Limited customization.

Best for: Small businesses, local services, speed-critical launches.

For Simplicity: Webflow (8.5/10)

Design quality matches or exceeds Squarespace. More control over layouts. Similar price range ($18-45/mo vs. $23-65/mo).

Trade-off: Steep learning curve (3-6 months). Takes longer to build than Squarespace.

Best for: Designers willing to invest time in learning, design-led businesses.

Migration steps (the hard way)

Important: Squarespace doesn't allow content export. There's no "download my site" button. Migration is manual work. Plan for 4-6 hours, or pay a freelancer $200-400.

Step 1: Audit your Squarespace site (30 minutes)

List all pages. List all images (note filenames). List all blog posts. Map out your site structure. You'll need this to recreate everything.

Step 2: Download all assets (30-60 minutes)

Right-click and save every image. Or use Squarespace's built-in image manager to download in bulk. Save to organized folders: "hero images," "product photos," "blog images."

Step 3: Export all text content (1-2 hours)

Copy all text from each page into a Google Doc. Organize by page: "Home page," "About," "Services," etc. Include metadata (page titles, descriptions) for SEO. This is tedious but necessary.

Step 4: Choose and set up new platform (30 minutes)

Create account on Framer, 10Web, or Durable. Connect custom domain (or buy one if you were using Squarespace's default). Set up basic settings.

Step 5: Recreate site structure (1-2 hours)

Create all pages in new platform. Match Squarespace structure as closely as possible. Don't worry about exact design matching—it's impossible. Focus on content hierarchy and user flow.

Step 6: Copy content and rebuild (2-3 hours)

Paste text from Google Docs into new pages. Upload images. Recreate layouts manually. This takes the longest time. Use AI generation to speed up, then customize with your actual content.

Step 7: Set up redirects (30 minutes)

Keep Squarespace live for 30 days. Map old URLs to new URLs using 301 redirects. This preserves SEO. After 30 days, cancel Squarespace and remove redirects.

SEO preservation during migration

The #1 migration fear: Losing search rankings. Done right, migrations don't hurt SEO. Done wrong, you can lose months of progress.

Keep Squarespace live for 30 days

Don't cancel immediately. Build new site on subdomain (new.yoursite.com). Test everything. Only switch DNS when new site is perfect.

Match page URLs exactly

If Squarespace page is /services, make new page /services. Don't change /about-us to /about. URL changes hurt SEO.

Set up 301 redirects

Use redirect plugin or DNS-level redirects. Map every old URL to new URL. This tells Google "content moved permanently" and preserves rankings.

Keep meta titles and descriptions

Copy title tags and meta descriptions exactly. These are SEO signals. Changing them tells Google "this is different content."

Is migrating worth it?

Do it if:

  • Budget is a major concern (saving $180-480/year is real money)
  • You're comfortable rebuilding and learning new platforms
  • You want features Squarespace lacks (AI generation, WordPress power, CRM)
  • You value design flexibility over polished templates
  • You're technical enough to handle migration yourself (or budget $200-400 for freelancer)

Stay if:

  • You're happy with Squarespace's templates and features
  • Time is more valuable than money (migration takes 4-6 hours)
  • You're non-technical and don't want to learn new tools
  • Squarespace's support reliability is worth the premium
  • You've tried migrating before and returned (don't make the same mistake twice)

The break-even math:

Squarespace ($27/mo) → Framer ($15/mo) = $12/month savings. Migration takes 6 hours. If your time is worth $50/hour, migration cost = $300. Break-even: 25 months. If your time is worth $20/hour, migration cost = $120. Break-even: 10 months.

The brutal reality

Most Squarespace users shouldn't migrate. The platform is expensive but excellent. Templates are beautiful. Support is responsive. Things just work. The $15-40/month premium buys peace of mind.

But some should migrate. If you're paying $65/month for Squarespace Commerce and only using basic features, 10Web WooCommerce saves you money. If you're a photographer tired of "Squarespace-looking" portfolios, Framer's design quality is superior (9.5 vs 8.2). If you just need a simple functional site, Durable costs $12/month vs. Squarespace's $23/month.

The 63% return rate tells the story. Most people leave for price, then come back for quality. Migration is temporary pain for permanent savings—but only if the new platform actually meets your needs. Choose wisely.
